From the Economist 
“Afghan politics and optimism tend not to go hand in hand, so the quiet anticipation of recent days has been striking. America and the Taliban are due to sign a peace deal on February 29th after fighting one another for more than 18 years. It has been previewed by a week-long “reduction in violence” to show both sides are serious. Each seems to be sticking to it. Clashes appear to have fallen by around 90%. If that continues, the signing will go ahead in Qatar. Under the agreement, America will quickly reduce its troops in Afghanistan, from 12,000 to about 8,600. The Taliban will promise not to shelter terrorists and to begin negotiations with the Afghan government and other powerbrokers on how Afghanistan should be run. Further American troop reductions are expected if the deal holds. Forging a political agreement will be difficult. Whatever happens next, Afghans welcome the current respite.”
Deal is likely to be signed tomorrow.

The seven-day “reduction in violence” began on friday and if this agreement is successful, the US would move to sign a peace deal with the Taliban on February 29. But that is not the end of the peace process, meaning intra-Afghan talks will start after the U.S.-Taliban deal signing, which skeptics of the Trump administration's peace efforts have said will be the most difficult part. It's also the most critical, Afghan political analyst Haroun Mir and others say, because peace won't happen without political reconciliation in Afghanistan (which means going through heavy negotiations between the Afghan government and the Taliban and be able to make mutual concessions).
There are many challenges to address, such as whether the Taliban leaders negotiating in Doha can keep all the elements of their group in line once a deal is in place. Additionally, it remained unclear who would represent Kabul at the intra-Afghan talks. The Taliban have refused to talk to Ghani’s government and also denounced the election results, saying they will talk to government representatives only as ordinary Afghans, not as officials. Germany and Norway have both offered to host the all-Afghan talks, but no venue has been set. Pompeo did not say who would represent Kabul, only that talks “will build on this fundamental step to deliver a comprehensive and permanent cease-fire and the future political road map for Afghanistan.”

Talks between the Taliban and Afghan politicians on how to run the country will then begin. Will the truce last? This appears to be an important development in Afghanistan’s long search for peace. "The talks between the United States and the Taliban in Doha, Qatar, which were abruptly canceled by President Trump in September, are back on track. After several months of diplomatic regrouping, American and Taliban negotiators are once again on the verge of sealing a deal. The negotiators haven't revised the basic transaction they set out last August - an American commitment to withdraw troops from Afghanistan for a Taliban promise not to allow the country to be used by transnational terrorists. A Washington Post article reported "Abdul Salam Hanafi, a senior Taliban leader and member of the political commission in Doha, Qatar, said in a video message shared with journalists that after negotiations, 'both sides have initiated the final draft of the peace agreement. Now talks are concluded.'" This statement is the first formal Taliban statement since the peace process started months ago. If the Taliban spokesperson is saying that a deal is close, the likelihood of a deal is much higher than if solely the United States stated that it was close. The fact that the US envoy Zalmay Khalilzad said he was "cautiously optimistic" about the deal also reinforces the likelihood of a deal being formalized. This coming weeks news on whether the imposition of a reduction in violence will actually be met will foretell whether both sides are actually serious about the proposed deal. Today, February 17 2020, Mullah Abdul Salam Hanafi, a senior Taliban leader, told journalists “both sides have initiated the final draft of the peace agreement. Now talks are concluded” and the Taliban claimed that a peace deal with the United States will be signed by the end of the month. While the United States and Taliban are in the midst of creating a complimentary environment for the signing of the peace agreement, they are also in almost the same position as they were in September when Trump and the Taliban had an agreement, before an attack that killed a U.S. soldier ended it. Moreover, the news of a potential agreement comes despite continued attacks by the Taliban, and “The Pentagon chief said if the process goes forward there would be continuous evaluation of any violence.” Just as the agreement entails the withdrawal of U.S. troops, the Taliban’s claim to suspend any attack on the West, and a seven day “reduction in violence”, it is important to note talks between the Taliban and the Afghan government, and how their relationship influences how the United States responds to peace negotiations moving forward, in addition to President Trump’s reelection strategies. fas.org

News has emerged that the signing of a peace agreement may be imminent. "The United States and the Taliban have agreed to a temporary truce...Details were provided separately Friday by a senior U.S. official and a Taliban official" [1]. The U.S. official said the agreement includes a seven-day "reduction in violence" and that a peace agreement would be signed within 10 days if the Taliban upholds this commitment. The Taliban official said that the signing has been "tentatively set for Feb. 29" and that the agreement would provide for the release of 5,000 Taliban prisoners before the start of the negotiations.  In other words, peace is actively being agreed upon by both sides but there is still a key step that must be successfully undertaken for the final signing of a peace agreement to take place. In particular, the Taliban will have to reduce violence to a significant extent as part of the aforementioned seven-day "reduction in violence" period. The possibility of such a successful temporary cessation of hostilities is very much in doubt - in fact, back in September a similar peace deal was also agreed to in principle only to collapse due to an unexpected Taliban attack. The possibility of such a scenario occurring again seems high - "It is still not entirely clear exactly who the US is talking to and to what extent they represent or speak for all Taliban elements....There are all sorts of other armed groups in Afghanistan eager to stir up trouble" [2]  Overall, I think it is still slightly more likely than not that no peace agreement will be signed in this question's time frame - however, this recent news has caused me to revise my forecast of the probability of the signing of such an agreement upward. My prior was 0.1. I think we would see this kind of news of an imminent deal in almost all cases of a deal actually happening, so I'll guesstimate p(B|A), where B is this news and A is an eventual signed deal, at ~0.95. I also think we would see news of an impending deal in many situations where a deal doesn't happen, including this same peace process last year. Many of these processes get close and then break down at the point where one or both parties are required to make actual concessions. So I'll guesstimate p(B|notA) at ~0.5. So, do the math and...my posterior is 0.17.

Base case: US signed 3 x bilateral peace treaties at end of WWI (Germany, Austria, and Hungary), 3 x multilateral peace treaties at end of WWII (Paris, San Francisco, and Berlin), 1 x bilateral at end of Vietnam War. There was no peace treaty after Korea, Desert Storm, or OIF. Taliban is active adversary still in Afghanistan, so WWI, WWII, and Vietnam are better parallels. Base case, then, is 80%.

Edit: Found some more information about seasonal violence in Afghanistan. Every year since the 2001 invasion, the Taliban has ramped up violence in the spring, commonly known as the "fighting season". Last year, the Taliban was unable to make meaningful gains during the spring months, but nonetheless began an offensive (https://media.defense.gov/2020/Jan/23/2002238296/-1/-1/1/1225-REPORT-DECEMBER-2019.PDF , 19-22). The history of U.S.-Taliban negotiations, with at least 4-5 substantive rounds of negotiations failed since 2011, suggests starting with a low estimate. The latest round of talks, which began in 2018 and ended in September 2019 with the U.S. President's decision to end negotiations in response to continued Taliban attacks on U.S. forces, had reportedly reached agreement on a draft deal including a timeline for withdrawal of U.S. forces. Negotiations over the U.S. withdrawal from Vietnam could be considered as a parallel, and that agreement was reached within a few months of President Nixon's reelection on a promise of "peace with honor". That said, the political focus on Vietnam within the U.S. electorate was quite different, so perhaps it's not a helpful analogy. This question closes the day the DNC opens, doesn't indicate that the peace agreement needs to be durable, and doesn't preclude separation from a follow-on round of even more contentious talks among Afghan parties, so it's hard for me not to look at this question from the perspective of the U.S. election cycle and the U.S. President's promise to end the U.S. commitment in Afghanistan. While I'm generally skeptical of the prospects given 9 years of failed negotiations, the potential for a political decision to agree to terms similar to those already agreed upon in 2019, even without changed facts on the ground, bumps up my estimate, along with recent reporting that the Taliban have offered a partial stand-down as part of a dialogue with the U.S. that renewed in early December.

There are no easy answers in Afghanistan.  The number of interdependent issues even made headlines in 2009/2010 with GEN McChrystal's complexity diagram.  Though the diagram was derided by many it only scratches the surface of the competing interests and overlapping allegiances of the people, politics, religion, and economy of the county.   The question of a peace agreement is one of time and interest.  President Trump has said it is in the U.S. interest to end the war and bring Soldiers home (probably before a November 2020 election).  The Taliban believes it is in its interest to end the war with the U.S. and end 'foreign occupation' of Afghanistan.  These two circles have a great deal of potential overlap, but the divergent element is the elected government of Afghanistan.  The 2019 elections had poor turnout and the current President Ashraf Ghani was identified as the preliminary winner, but this result was challenged by his chief rival.  The situation is similar to the last election which required the U.S. to negotiate a power sharing agreement between the two.  Though nominally sharing power over this term, the government has been ineffective in many area.  A weak mandate among only a portion of the population has not set the government up for success.   The Taliban almost certainly sees this as a positive outcome, but could approach it two ways: continue to refuse meeting with an 'illegitimate' Afghan government, seek to meet and dominate a weak government.  Past behavior would indicate the first option.  Though the U.S. resumed negotiations with the Taliban after the elections - almost certainly with some understanding of the outcome - there doesn't seem to be an indication of how the U.S. will reconcile the status of the Afghan government in a Peace Agreement with the Taliban.  The spectre of history and the U.S. withdrawal from Vietnam would loom large if a decision was made to fully depart (a Taliban requirement) without an agreement on government's status.   The second factor is time - While winter has been a time of reduced violence in the past (environmental factors contributing), spring is a time for poppy harvest and the initiation of new offensives.  To be effective an agreement would need to be achieved prior the winter thaw and the conflict which inevitably occurs around the nesh.  The poppy harvest in Afghanistan is a multi-billion dollar event.  Whether the violence is between drug producers-transporters-protectors-government or some combination thereof, the increased level of violence would be a disruptive element in negotiations.  Traditionally, the talk of peace is normally at its height in the winter, but fades as the potential profit from the poppies grows to maturity and Taliban elements gain access to more money.  In 2020, a central government with a weak mandate may only encourage the Taliban to seek a military victory even more.     While possible - a fully concluded peace agreement is unlikely. The perseverance of the Taliban in Doha was unusual, especially given its concerns about participant legitimacy.  It was here the leadership confirmed the death of Taliban Head Mullah Omar and received news of his successor Mullah Akhtar Mohammad Mansour being killed in a drone strike in Pakistan.  They had every reason to walk away, yet they did not.  This event begs the question if they were looking for a way out, similar to the U.S. strategy in Afghanistan.  The U.S. and the Taliban are in a mutually hurting stalemate.   It is likely the only way that Afghanistan can achieve sustainable peace and stability is through dialogue and negotiations, and third-party mediation remains the optimal solution for reaching an agreement in the Afghan conflict.  This claim does not suggest that the Afghan government is incapable of securing a peace deal.  In September 2016, it penned a successful agreement with Hezb-e Islami marking the first major success of Afghanistan in reaching a peace deal with an insurgent group.  Third-party intervention is required for the Afghan conflict simply due to the number of stakeholders involved.  Complex problems have complex solutions, and we now see the significance of inclusion during the peace process.  The conflict is ripe for negotiations.  By communicating through good faith, conforming to legitimacy, and achieving a better understanding of each other, participants will be able to get the Afghan peace process back on track.

I assume the central questions here represent the following: - Is it more probable that the US withdraws with or without an agreement with the Taliban?
- Is a withdrawal of US troops probable before the next US election? From my first impression, I've had assumed that a US withdrawal with a peace agreement - no matter the details - would be seen more favorable by the US government than a withdrawal without a peace agreement which would not only inofficially but also officially show US defeat in Afghanistan. However, statements by Defense Secretary Esper let me conclude that a peace agreement may not be necessary to withdraw US troops at all [1, 4]. This may be a political move to avoid the impression that the Taliban just have to wait until the next election to get an agreement by the US - how shallow it may be. On the other hand, the incentive to remove all troops may not even be given in the case that it is seen as more costly politically [2, 3, 5]. Therefore, a lot depends on the Taliban's approach to the negotiations. At the moment I assume the status quo to be more probable. This may change if the political costs to stay in Afghanistan outweigh any possible shallow peace agreement.
